The Jay
MANY of us have heard a well-substantiated report that operations of the
Blue Jay bid fair to be curtailed for
next year, due partly to the lack of available Student Activity Council appropriation and partly to its failure to be a good
literary comic magazine.
Of course, it might be expected that
we'd mourn the passing of a contemporary journalitic enterprise of such proximity as the Jay's. For many years we've
held joint bull sessions and lent our type2
writers back and forth, so that we probably should experience a feeling of remorse.
On the contrary, though, we're forced
to join in the , sentiment of the undergraduate campus which believes, frankly,
that the Jay is no good. The jokes aren't
funny enough; the articles are too labored—lack buoyancy and cleverness.
After reading an issue one feels as though
the staff has just made a noble effort and
is breathing a sigh of relief at having one
more issue in the mail boxes.
One very unfortunate aspect presents
itself, however. That is that the authorities are shaking the big stick at the Jay
at the conclusion of Miss Howser's term
of editorship. If the Jay goes now, it is
quite probable that her regime will bear
the stigma of failure, of which, in our
opinion, it is totally undeserving. Her
performance has been commendable in
the face of such serious obstacles as lack
of contributing talent, depleted cash resources, and the antagonistic mental attitude of those who have resented the
presence of a girl in the editorship position.
So we take this opportunity of re-

one seems to have overlooked, although it is altogether practicable,
and desirable, and in full accord
with the spirit of our times.
The idea of making professional
scholars out of all men may seem
revolutionary, but it must be realized that society has progressed to
that point where it is no longer necessary for the majority of men to
engage in the ordinary pursuits of
life and that the time has come when
man should turn more of his energies to higher pursuits of civilized
life—art, music, and the furtherance
of knowledge. It is especially in the
last-named field that such a dearth
of labor exists, a deficiency which
could very well be made up from
the present ranks of the unemployed.
It will then become possible to proceed with the great task of classifying and coordinating human
knowledge, a task in which all men
could and should have a share.
It will be objected, of course, that
this only solves part of the problem.
The second part of the problem has
to do with the sustenance of these
men while in the pursuit of their
research problems. Here the writer
wishes to make a suggestion which
seems at first blush revolutionary
and hence undesirable, but which,
when viewed in its true light, is absolutely in conformity with present
economic policies.

According to the Muhlenberg
Weekly, a professor at Marshall
College, head of the public speaking
department, maintains that "a girl
covers three-quarters of her personality when she puts on a coat." ..
Ahem!
* * *
In executing her role as sorority
pledge a certain coed, at the University of Texas, nonchalantly
stopped a street car, tied her shoe
string on the steps, and thanked the
conductor very kindly.
It is a well known fact that most
of the money in this country is concentrated in the hands of a very few
people. Your correspondent proposes that the public, instead of
waiting to be deprived of all its
money, surrender the same immediately into the hands of these few
individuals and throw the entire responsibility of managing their economic affairs onto their shoulders.
Let these individuals, in addition,
put the numerous students engaged
in research work at the universities
under their employ. Speculation,
usury, graft, and all existing commercial vices and depravities will
despair; men will no longer have
to worry about their daily sustenance and human kind will be free
suits of civilized life.
WILLIAM SQUAIR.

Washington and Lee, maintain chapters of the fraternity.

are Arthur Brisbane, editor and columnist; Frederick William Wile,

Stephen Leacock, humorist; Warren

famous author.

treasurer; Hyman Levin, Gordon
Green, Gordon Biggs, Mortimer
Katz, and Haskell Milstone.

POEM CONTRIBUTIONS
To Sponsor Inter-Collegiate Exhibit
In Anthology; Five Per
Person Is Limit
Hopkins students have been invited by the Poet's Guild of New
York to submit poems for the Inter-Collegiate Exhibit in Anthology
at the World's Fair.
The number of poems which may
be submitted by any one person is
limited to five. Poems on any subject and in any form will be accepted. The conditions specified by
the Poet's Guild of New York are:
all manuscripts should be typewritten, double-spaced, with the title,
author's name, and college at the
top of each sheet; poems should be
on 82 x 11 inch paper; no poems
can be considered after April 1; and
no manuscripts will be returned.
All poems should be submitted to
Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles, professor of
English.

Dean Of Engineering
At Purdue University
Lectures At Hopkins
"What is Ahead of the Student
of Engineering of Today" was the
topic of an address by Dean A. A.
Potter of the School of Engineering of Purdue University delivered
to engineering students in their third
and fourth years in Maryland Hall
yesterday.
Dr. Potter is also the president
of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

ILLUSION:
In India, the fakirs present a spectacle to tourists.
Two lovely performers break bottles and lamp
chimneys before the eyes of the audience,and throw
the jagged pieces into a box already filled with
broken glass. They step barefooted into the box
and do an Oriental dance in the glass without in-

jury.

EXPLANATION:
The performers toughen their feet irf a strong solution of alum water and thoroughly rub them
with pulverized resin before they appear. They
throw the freshly broken glass around the edges of
the platform. The glass on which they actually do
dance is very thick, heavy, and filed or ground so
that the sharp edges are rounded off. The girls
just Pretend to dance on the sharp glass.

G. S. Sloan, Banker, To
Address Liberal Club
Tonight
George S. Sloan, vice-president of
the First National Bank will speak
at a meeting of the Liberal Club tonight at 8 p. m. The topic of his
address will be "The Recent Banking Situation."
A former National Bank executive and official of the Federal Reserve Bank in Richmond, Virginia,
Mr. Sloan will explain the significance of the recent banking moratorium to the practical banker.

The Jay
MANY of us have heard a well-substantiated report that operations of the
Blue Jay bid fair to be curtailed for
next year, due partly to the lack of available Student Activity Council appropriation and partly to its failure to be a good
literary comic magazine.
Of course, it might be expected that
we'd mourn the passing of a contemporary journalitic enterprise of such proximity as the Jay's. For many years we've
held joint bull sessions and lent our type2
writers back and forth, so that we probably should experience a feeling of remorse.
On the contrary, though, we're forced
to join in the , sentiment of the undergraduate campus which believes, frankly,
that the Jay is no good. The jokes aren't
funny enough; the articles are too labored—lack buoyancy and cleverness.
After reading an issue one feels as though
the staff has just made a noble effort and
is breathing a sigh of relief at having one
more issue in the mail boxes.
One very unfortunate aspect presents
itself, however. That is that the authorities are shaking the big stick at the Jay
at the conclusion of Miss Howser's term
of editorship. If the Jay goes now, it is
quite probable that her regime will bear
the stigma of failure, of which, in our
opinion, it is totally undeserving. Her
performance has been commendable in
the face of such serious obstacles as lack
of contributing talent, depleted cash resources, and the antagonistic mental attitude of those who have resented the
presence of a girl in the editorship position.
So we take this opportunity of re-

one seems to have overlooked, although it is altogether practicable,
and desirable, and in full accord
with the spirit of our times.
The idea of making professional
scholars out of all men may seem
revolutionary, but it must be realized that society has progressed to
that point where it is no longer necessary for the majority of men to
engage in the ordinary pursuits of
life and that the time has come when
man should turn more of his energies to higher pursuits of civilized
life—art, music, and the furtherance
of knowledge. It is especially in the
last-named field that such a dearth
of labor exists, a deficiency which
could very well be made up from
the present ranks of the unemployed.
It will then become possible to proceed with the great task of classifying and coordinating human
knowledge, a task in which all men
could and should have a share.
It will be objected, of course, that
this only solves part of the problem.
The second part of the problem has
to do with the sustenance of these
men while in the pursuit of their
research problems. Here the writer
wishes to make a suggestion which
seems at first blush revolutionary
and hence undesirable, but which,
when viewed in its true light, is absolutely in conformity with present
economic policies.

According to the Muhlenberg
Weekly, a professor at Marshall
College, head of the public speaking
department, maintains that "a girl
covers three-quarters of her personality when she puts on a coat." ..
Ahem!
* * *
In executing her role as sorority
pledge a certain coed, at the University of Texas, nonchalantly
stopped a street car, tied her shoe
string on the steps, and thanked the
conductor very kindly.
It is a well known fact that most
of the money in this country is concentrated in the hands of a very few
people. Your correspondent proposes that the public, instead of
waiting to be deprived of all its
money, surrender the same immediately into the hands of these few
individuals and throw the entire responsibility of managing their economic affairs onto their shoulders.
Let these individuals, in addition,
put the numerous students engaged
in research work at the universities
under their employ. Speculation,
usury, graft, and all existing commercial vices and depravities will
despair; men will no longer have
to worry about their daily sustenance and human kind will be free
suits of civilized life.
WILLIAM SQUAIR.

POETS GUILD INVITES
STUDENT WORLD'S FAIR
POEM CONTRIBUTIONS
To Sponsor Inter-Collegiate Exhibit
In Anthology; Five Per
Person Is Limit
Hopkins students have been invited by the Poet's Guild of New
York to submit poems for the Inter-Collegiate Exhibit in Anthology
at the World's Fair.
The number of poems which may
be submitted by any one person is
limited to five. Poems on any subject and in any form will be accepted. The conditions specified by
the Poet's Guild of New York are:
all manuscripts should be typewritten, double-spaced, with the title,
author's name, and college at the
top of each sheet; poems should be
on 82 x 11 inch paper; no poems
can be considered after April 1; and
no manuscripts will be returned.
All poems should be submitted to
Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles, professor of
English.

Dean Of Engineering
At Purdue University
Lectures At Hopkins
"What is Ahead of the Student
of Engineering of Today" was the
topic of an address by Dean A. A.
Potter of the School of Engineering of Purdue University delivered
to engineering students in their third
and fourth years in Maryland Hall
yesterday.
Dr. Potter is also the president
of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

ILLUSION:
In India, the fakirs present a spectacle to tourists.
Two lovely performers break bottles and lamp
chimneys before the eyes of the audience,and throw
the jagged pieces into a box already filled with
broken glass. They step barefooted into the box
and do an Oriental dance in the glass without in-

jury.

EXPLANATION:
The performers toughen their feet irf a strong solution of alum water and thoroughly rub them
with pulverized resin before they appear. They
throw the freshly broken glass around the edges of
the platform. The glass on which they actually do
dance is very thick, heavy, and filed or ground so
that the sharp edges are rounded off. The girls
just Pretend to dance on the sharp glass.
SOURCE:"Magic Stage Illusions and Scientific Diversions"

G. S. Sloan, Banker, To
Address Liberal Club
Tonight
George S. Sloan, vice-president of
the First National Bank will speak
at a meeting of the Liberal Club tonight at 8 p. m. The topic of his
address will be "The Recent Banking Situation."
A former National Bank executive and official of the Federal Reserve Bank in Richmond, Virginia,
Mr. Sloan will explain the significance of the recent banking moratorium to the practical banker.
